tweet:
Everyone's vibe coding.

Almost nobody knows what they're actually building.

That's why most AI-built apps break at 70% and never ship.

I mapped out the 12 things you need to understand, not to become a developer, but to actually ship something real:

→ How the web works

This is the worst bug I've run into since the @openclaw update and I can't figure it out. Who can help please? I want to cry @steipete https://t.co/b8Upe5x2rT

RAG systems are collapsing at scale.
I started noticing something strange with enterprise AI deployments.
The demos looked great.
The first few hundred documents worked beautifully.
Then everything quietly fell apart. 🧵 https://t.co/0t31ThiX0U

How I test every app before launch:

1. Ship to TestFlight

2. Get my mom to download the app

3. Facetime her and watch where she gets stuck

4. Fix the friction

If she asks “what do I do here?” → that’s a bug https://t.co/nxaLHYr5KT

✅ OT needs different telemetry

Ankur’s test is simple: when users discover he’s the founder, are they surprised?

He stays close to support tickets for a reason. If leaders step away from raw feedback, Ankur believes they lose empathy, and without empathy, accountability slips.

Shipping in public: I just added real-time public stats —  (and counting) + live inboxes created. It keeps me honest and it’s a forcing function for growth. What’s one metric you’d feel confident tracking publicly? #buildinpublic
Building in public isn't just transparency. it's your entire content engine running while you ship

Build-in-public is often the wrong move for brands still figuring out their product, positioning, or winning formulation.

The messiness confuses the audience and creates very little value.

Ironically, build-in-public works best for established brands.

professor has us acting out random words in monologues and it feels soooooo wrong because you can’t say what the piece is and you’re not using any other information from it you literally just have to use one word

I's indistinguishable from L's and T's. E's indistinguishable from F's. Multiple words get disjointed--not just on one plane but two.
Truly, one of the most headache-inducing reading experiences I've ever had. https://t.co/hohr6Whusy

This test is not supposed to easy. It is meant to be challenging as hell. If you get overwhelmed and frustrated, it is not because you are weak. It is because you are a student.  It is OK to be in your feelings every now and then. This test is not easy.

for todays test you have to make an aromantic character that isnt:

extremely cheerful/childish
evil
"currently not looking for a relationship"
prefers books over people

As a playwright I’ve been rejected by every theater & playwriting competition I can think of. Now I have network execs requesting to read my plays. Moral of the story: keep writing that script. It may seem like no one wants it. But it may be the thing to usher u into your dre

Apparently, writing a complex character is now a “plot hole that just doesn’t add up”

“Sometimes the show appears uncertain about how it wants us to feel about either of them.” Maybe it’s because that’s what they want to convey ? https://t.co/AbxLLPC4yg

I think many writers get stuck because they try to write a novel without having practiced writing much before. They are not at ease with personification, descriptive body language, transitions, dialogue, etc. It’s like trying to paint a fresco with zero preparatory drawings.

Zahara Chowdhury, an English teacher claims Shakespeare is just “too hard” and should be dropped from the syllabus, while they assure us that standards really aren’t declining. https://t.co/SHxk5kNK4s

Acting is tough... BUT teaching is like putting on 6 improv shows a day, where the audience talks and constantly interrupts you, and the audience has to pass a test at the end to ensure that they were paying attention.

When people go to see a school play not many complain about the ‘rote learning’ of the script and the stressful ‘test’ of the performance where the fine line between failure and success is exposed to immediate feedback from the audience.

Part of the issue w/ AP Eng Lit performance: the exam only has one question focused on a novel/play, but much class time is spent on long texts rather than close reading/analysis of short fiction/poetry. Top advice: reduce the # of novels/plays; focus on frequent short analyses.

"I think I'd like to be a playwright."
"You'll face constant rejection."
"That's okay."
"You'll make zero money."
"That's fine."
"You may have to reformat your play to adhere to Yale Drama Series contest guidelines."
"Oh, in that case, forget it."
My pretentious opinion is that Shakespeare is neither inaccessible nor alienating, you just don't want to read anything that makes you think hard.

Problem: We need to fix a production bug, but the development branch contains work that isn’t ready for prod.

Solution: Only merge code to that can be immediately deployed. Use feature flags to hide incomplete work.

Keep the development branch production worthy.
